skill.name: tool-design
skill.description: This skill should be used when the user asks to "design agent tools", "create tool descriptions", "reduce tool complexity", "implement MCP tools", or mentions tool consolidation, architectural reduction, tool naming conventions, or agent-tool interfaces.

skill.author: ChakshuGautam

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation and guidance skill containing no executable code that poses security risks. The Python file contains only template definitions and class structures for generating tool descriptions. No network calls, file system access beyond own files, environment variable reading, or external command execution.

content.value_statement: Agents fail when tools are poorly designed. This skill provides systematic approaches to create tool descriptions, consolidate functionality, and reduce complexity following proven patterns from production systems.
actual_capabilities: Create tool descriptions that clearly explain what, when, and what returns
Apply consolidation principle to reduce tool ambiguity
Design MCP tools with fully qualified naming conventions
Optimize response formats for token efficiency
Build error messages that enable agent recovery
Evaluate tool designs against clarity and completeness criteria
limitations: Does not generate executable code for tool implementations
Does not integrate with external tool frameworks directly
Does not validate tools against running systems
Focuses on design patterns rather than framework-specific implementation

use_cases.title: Design new agent tools
use_cases.description: Create tool definitions from scratch following consolidation and naming conventions for reliable agent interactions.

use_cases.title: Audit existing tools
use_cases.description: Review and optimize current tool collections to reduce ambiguity and improve agent success rates.

use_cases.title: Implement MCP tools
use_cases.description: Build MCP-compatible tools with proper server prefixes and schema definitions for multi-server environments.

prompt_templates.title: Create new tool
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a tool for querying the customer database. Include description, parameters for filtering and pagination, return format, and error cases with recovery guidance.

prompt_templates.title: Consolidate tools
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my current tool collection for [domain] and identify opportunities to consolidate overlapping tools while maintaining clear purpose for each.

prompt_templates.title: Optimize descriptions
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze the attached tool descriptions for clarity issues. Identify vague language, missing parameters, and ambiguous triggers that could cause agent failures.

prompt_templates.title: Design architecture
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a minimal tool architecture for [use case] following architectural reduction principles. Explain when reduction works and when specialized tools are necessary.

output_examples.input: Create a tool for reading file contents in the sandbox
output: Description: Read file contents from the sandbox environment
When to use: User asks to view, search, or analyze file contents
Parameters: path (required, file path), format (optional, 'text' or 'json')
Returns: Object with content field and metadata
Errors: NOT_FOUND for missing files, PERMISSION_DENIED for access issues

best_practices: Write descriptions that answer what the tool does, when to use it, and what it returns
Use consolidation to reduce tool count when a human cannot clearly distinguish which tool to use
Include concrete examples showing parameter formats and common usage patterns
anti_patterns: Using vague descriptions like 'search the database' without specifying what databases and what formats
Creating many narrow tools with overlapping functionality that confuses agent selection
Missing error handling or providing generic error messages that offer no recovery guidance

faq.question: What platforms support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Claude Code, and Codex. Tool design principles apply broadly across LLM-based agent systems.

faq.question: How many tools should my agent have?
faq.answer: Research suggests 10-20 tools for most applications. Use namespacing to organize larger collections while keeping the effective tool set manageable.

faq.question: How does this integrate with MCP?
faq.answer: Use fully qualified names like 'ServerName:tool_name' to avoid conflicts when multiple MCP servers are registered. Include server context in all tool references.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using these patterns?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill provides design guidance only and does not execute code, access files, or make network requests on your system.

faq.question: When should I avoid architectural reduction?
faq.answer: Avoid reduction when data is messy, domain requires specialized knowledge, safety constraints limit access, or workflows genuinely benefit from structured orchestration.

faq.question: How is this different from traditional API design?
faq.answer: Traditional APIs target developers who understand systems. Tools target language models that infer intent from descriptions, requiring unambiguous descriptions, examples, and recovery guidance.
